The Comptroller General may establish senior-level positions to meet critical scientific, technical, or professional needs of the Office. Individuals in these positions are subject to laws and regulations applicable to the General Accounting Office Senior Executive Service. The Comptroller General may establish senior-level positions to meet critical scientific, technical, or professional needs of the Office. Individuals in these positions have the same rights of appeal, exemptions from certain laws, entitlement to retirement benefits, and can be reassigned to other Senior Executive Service positions as determined by the Comptroller General. The table of sections for chapter 7 of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new item after section 732. SEC. 2. Reassignment to senior level positions allows the Comptroller General to move Senior Executive Service members to new senior-level positions. SEC. 3. Experts and consultants now have 3-year renewable terms and are at level IV. SEC. 4. Voluntary early retirement authority. Section 732 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to provide annuity benefits for General Accounting Office employees meeting specific service and age criteria. The amendment to Section 732 of title 31, United States Code, provides annuity benefits for General Accounting Office employees meeting certain criteria, including not having received a decision notice of involuntary separation for misconduct, being separated voluntarily during a period of workforce realignment, and being treated as an employee entitled to an annuity under specific sections of title 5 for computation purposes. The Comptroller General will issue regulations for implementation. The Comptroller General will issue regulations for implementing early retirement offers based on skills, knowledge, performance, or other factors for General Accounting Office employees. The terms 'employee' and 'annuity' have the same meaning as defined in title 5. The authority granted under this subsection cannot be used to grant voluntary early retirements to more than 10 percent of the workforce in any fiscal year. SEC. 5. SEPARATION PAY. Section 732 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to offer separation pay to officers or employees for realigning the workforce. The pay can be in a lump sum or installments, and is capped at $25,000 or the amount entitled under section 5595(c) of title 5. The amendment to Section 732 of title 31, United States Code, allows the Comptroller General to offer separation pay to officers or employees for workforce realignment. The pay is capped at $25,000 or the amount entitled under section 5595(c) of title 5. The pay shall not be a basis for other government benefits, severance pay calculations, or be paid to reemployed annuitants. The amendment to Section 732 of title 31, United States Code allows the Comptroller General to offer separation pay to officers or employees for workforce realignment. The pay is capped at $25,000 or the amount entitled under section 5595(c) of title 5. It shall not be a basis for other government benefits, severance pay calculations, or be paid to reemployed annuitants. Separation pay terminates upon reemployment in the Federal Government, and must be repaid if reemployed within 5 years. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management may waive repayment if the individual has unique abilities and is the only qualified applicant available for the position in the agency, legislative branch, or judicial branch. The individual with unique abilities may have repayment waived for the position if they are the only qualified applicant available. Separation pay is based on skills, knowledge, and performance factors determined by the Comptroller General. 45 percent of the final annual basic pay is remitted to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund by the General Accounting Office. Separation pay under subchapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5 is remitted to employees, in addition to other payments required by the General Accounting Office. The term 'final basic pay' refers to the total basic pay for a year of service, based on the employee's final rate of basic pay. This payment is limited to 5 percent of the General Accounting Office's workforce in a fiscal year. Employees of the General Accounting Office are eligible for separation pay for a period of 5 years after the enactment of this section, unless Congress extends the authority. SEC. 6. REDUCTION IN FORCE. Section 732(h) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to prescribe regulations for releasing officers and employees of the General Accounting Office in a reduction in force. Employees must receive written notice at least 60 days before being released. The Comptroller General can prescribe regulations for releasing employees in a reduction in force, including specifying personnel actions, effective dates, procedures for identifying employees, ranking criteria, and appeal rights. The notice period can be shortened to a minimum of 30 days in unforeseen circumstances. SEC. 7. ANNUAL REPORT. Section 719 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include appropriate legislative changes to sections 732(h), (i), and (j) of this title. In subsection (b)(1), a description of the actions taken under sections 732(h), (i), and (j) of this title is required. The amendment includes reporting on sections 732(h), (i), and (j) of the title, detailing employee early retirements, separation pay, and effectiveness of human capital initiatives in achieving agency goals. SEC. 8. FIVE-YEAR ASSESSMENT. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress after 5 years, detailing the implementation and effectiveness of the Act. The report will include summaries of annual reports, recommendations for legislative changes, and assessments from various groups within the General Accounting Office.
